Grouping and Summarizing

Our Data

Letâ€™s work with the dataset m111survey from the {bcscr} package:

DT::datatable(m111survey, options = list(scrollX = TRUE))

Setup

Use the inputs below to select a categorical variable and a numerical variable from m111survey: weâ€™ll work with your choices for the rest of the tutorial.

viewof category = Inputs.select(
  categoricals,
  { value: ["seat"], label: "Category" }
);
viewof measure = Inputs.select(
  [ "fastest", "GPA", "height", "ideal_height", "sleep" ],
  { label: "Numerical Measure" }
);

Hereâ€™s a graphical display for your choices:

p <- ggplot(data = m111survey, aes(x = ${category}, y = ${measure})) +
  geom_violin(fill = "burlywood") +
  geom_jitter(width = 0.25, size = 0.5) +
  labs(title = "Violin Studies")
ggplotly(p)

Exercises

Computing Groupwise Means

  • Exercise
  • Solution

Use {dplyr} manipulations to compute the mean value of the measure you chose: for each value of . Name the mean m. Your goal is the following table:

Start by grouping according to .

m111survey |> group_by(${category})

After you have grouped, use summarize() to compute the mean within each group:

m111survey |> group_by(${category}) |> 
  summarize(m = mean(${measure}))

Remember that the na.rm = TRUE option will compute means after removing NA-values:

m111survey |> group_by(${category}) |> 
  summarize(m = mean(${measure}, na.rm = TRUE))
m111survey |> group_by(${category}) |> 
  summarize(m = mean(${measure}))

Counting Groups

Earlier you chose the categorical variable . The following bar graph offers a visualization of the relative sizes of the groups formed by the values of this variable:

ggplot(m111survey, aes(x = ${category})) +
  geom_bar(
      fill = "skyblue", 
      color = "black"
  )
  • Exercise
  • Solution

Use {dplyr} manipulations to compute the sizes of the sub-groups formed by breaking down the groups formed by the values of . Name the column of group-sizes size. Your goal is the following table:

Start by grouping according to the :

m111survey |> group_by(${category})

When you summarize, use the function n() to count the number of rows in each group.

m111survey |>
  group_by(${category}) |> 
  summarize(size = n())

Of course, count() is a shortcut:

m111survey |>
  count(${category})

Groups and Subgroups

Pick a second categorical variable, different than the one you have already chosen:

catLeft = {
  const newArray = categoricals.filter(item => item !== category);
  return(newArray);
}
viewof category2 = Inputs.select(
  catLeft,
  { value: catLeft[0], label: "Second Category" }
);

Here is a visualization of the different groups according to , broken into subgroups by the values of :

ggplot(m111survey, aes(x = ${category})) +
  geom_bar(
      aes(fill = ${category2}), 
      color = "black",
      position = "dodge"
  )
  • Exercise
  • Solution

Use {dplyr} manipulations to compute the sizes of the sub-groups formed by breaking down the groups formed by the values of by each value of . Name the column of group-sizes size. Your goal is the following table:

Start by grouping according to and then according to :

m111survey |> group_by(${category}, ${category2})

When you summarize, use the function n() to count the number of rows in each group.

m111survey |>
  group_by(${category}, ${category2}) |> 
  summarize(size = n())

Of course, count() is a shortcut:

m111survey |>
  count(${category}, ${category2})
